title: How to write a college essay in two days - Quora

response.answer_text: Okay, first finish panicking, if you do not get the panic out of your system, you are doomed since all you will think about the deadline and nothing else will. If you can, ask for an extension on the deadline but if your college is strict, you are going to need a good excuse. Second, stop procrastinating about not knowing what to write, you do, it really won’t feel like it but you do. Pick a start time and go from there, do not deviate. Third look at the prompt, since you mentioned college essays and mine were about 2000 words I will assume yours are about the same, break it down into themes and review your notes. Your notes will have the answer, if you can’t find it in them or it’s a creative writing type prompt or college application prompt, stick the prompt through a thesaurus and rewrite it until it makes sense. Try about four themes, 400 words or 20% of the total word count per theme and link them, forget about an opening paragraph and your conclusion for now which can be formulated at the end of writing from the meat of the essay. 10% of the total word count should go to the opening paragraph and 10% - 15% conclusion. The above will make a first draft. Go for a walk, eat, take a bath, play a game or something to relax. Revise the essay by reading it aloud, by reading aloud you’ll change how you perceive your own writing. Fix the errors, go to bed and hand it in on time. Breathe, it is more than a little doable in two days, unless its 20,000 words at which point I wish you luck and recommend a lot of caffeine.

Step one: Read the question carefully. Step two: Bullet point what will fulfill the essay’s requirements. Step three: Check the asked for word count, the format (font size and type, spacing, etc.) and set up your document accordingly. Step four: Your intro paragraph - it should have your core statement/hypothesis. Step five: The paragraphs that support your hypothesis. Each paragraph should be built around one of the bullets that supports the essay’s ask and your hypothesis. Step six: Your conclusion should wrap up what you’ve just said in a tight little paragraph. Step seven: Copy edit your essay. You can run it through a free program (I like Grammarly) that will catch a lot of errors. Then, go take a 20 minute nap or walk, come back, print out a copy and read it aloud in a speaking tone. Your ear will pick up other errors and you may discover some logic errors, clunky writing, etc. If the ask is for an experience essay, then don’t make stuff up. Think about your life to date and write about something real. In this case, Steps 1, 2, 3 and 7 still apply.

Here’s a tip that will make the task a lot easier: Almost certainly, there is no right or wrong answer. Don’t agonize over the “right” answer to whatever the prompt is. That’s not what the college is looking for. It’s looking for essays that: Specifically respond to the prompt and to the instructions. Answer the prompt directly, whatever it’s asking for. And if the instructions say “. . . no more than 2,000 words . . .” then make absolutely, 100% sure your essay is 1,999 words or less.Are written clearly. Check your grammar and spelling.Develop and defend your position. If the question is “Which is a better color: Red or blue?” you answer the question and defend your answer. As I said at the beginning, your answer itself is meaningless. It’s how you defend it.Red is a better color because: It is the color of blood, which embodies life itself.Red is the color of the sky at sunrise, offering the promise of a new day.On stop lights, it signifies “stop,” preventing injury or death to people who otherwise might drive through the intersection without stopping.Blue is a better color because: It is the color of the sky, offering nearly limitless possibilities.Blue is the color of the oceans as seen from space. Water gives life.It can be the color of a person’s eyes, offering a view into that person’s soul.OK, some of my examples are a bit strained. But the point is clear: Even with a nonsense question asking you to choose the better color, you can make a solid argument regardless of your position. That’s really what the college is interested in: Can you think logically and argue persuasively? So don’t worry about the answer itself. Just make sure you show how you get from Point A to Point B.

Hire a professional proofreader to help you with all the errors detecting and correcting. Thus, you will soon manage to achieve much in writing business and who knows, maybe you will soon realize that writing is your calling. It’s quite a nice try to earn some money.

It can be done- you will have to work with what you already have. Review your class notes and quickly read through the introductions of your text books to refresh your memory. If I were you, I would also apply to the college for an extension of time right now, while it’s still possible. If you don’t understand the question, then ask one of your class-mates to explain it to you. Brain-storm a few ideas and write them down. This should help. As long as you hand something reasonable in, you should be fine. It doesn’t have to be the best essay of all time- you only have to pass, so keep your expectations of yourself realistic. Don’t panic.
